facts.text: Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 699-703 of 1957 were filed by special leave from the decision of the Wage Board for Working Journalists.

anchor.surface_text: AND CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 699-703 of 1957. Appeals by special leave from the decision of the Wage Board for Working Journalists published in the Gazette of India Extraordinary  Part IT, Section 3  dated May 11, 1957.

facts.text: Wage Board decision for Working Journalists was published in the Gazette of India Extraordinary Part II, Section 3 dated May 11, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the decision of the Wage Board for Working Journalists published in the Gazette of India Extraordinary  Part IT, Section 3  dated May 11, 1957.

facts.text: Working Journalists Act, 1955 is claimed to be ultra vires as it infringes fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14 and 32.

anchor.surface_text: K. Nambiar and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the petitioners in Petition No. 91 of 1957. -The Working Journalists Act, 1955, is ultra vires as it infringes the fundamental rights of the Petitioners guaranteed by the Constitution under Arts. 19  1   a , 19  1   g , 14 and 32.

facts.text: Wage Board Rules were published on July 10, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The reconstitution of the Board oil the retirement of one of its members was ultra vires and unauthorised by the Act as it stood at the time, the Rules having been published on July 10, 1956.

facts.text: Government of Uttar Pradesh appointed a committee on June 18, 1947 to enquire into conditions of work of newspaper employees.

anchor.surface_text: On June 18, 1947, the Government of Uttar Pradesh appointed a companymittee to enquire into the companyditions of work of the employees of the newspaper industry in the Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Government of Central Provinces Berar appointed Inquiry Committee on March 27, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On March 27, 1948, the Government of Central Provinces Berar also appointed an Inquiry Committee to examine and report on certain questions relating to the general working of the newspaper industry in the province...

facts.text: Press Commission report submitted on July 14, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission companypleted its enquiry and submitted its report on July 14, 1954.

facts.text: Working Journalists Industrial Disputes Act, 1955 received assent on March 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Almost immediately after the Report of the Press Commission, Parliament passed the Working Journalists  Industrial Disputes  Act, 1955  I of 1955  which received the assent of the President on March 12, 1955.

facts.text: Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 received assent on December 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Act as finally passed was entituled The Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955  45 of 1955  and received the assent of the President on December 20, 1955.

facts.text: Central Government constituted Wage Board by notification dated May 2, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated May 2, 1956, the Central Government companystituted a Wage Board under s. 8 of the Act...

facts.text: Working Journalists Wage Board Rules, 1956 published in Gazette dated July 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the power given under s. 20 of the Act the Central Government published by a numberification in the Gazette of India-Part II-Section 3, dated July 30,1956, The Working Journalists Wage Board Rules, 1956...

facts.text: Press Commission announced on September 23, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment of the Press Commission was thereafter announced in a Communique issued by the Govt. of India... on September 23, 1952...

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 19, 1958 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. March 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-

facts.text: Out of 137 concerns, only 59 returned profits and 68 showed losses as per Press Commission.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst other things it found that out of 137 companycerns about whom information was available only 59 were returning profits and 68 showed losses.

facts.text: Newspaper industry returned profit of about 6 lakhs on capital of 7 crores, less than 1% per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The industry taken as a whole had returned a profit of about 6 lakhs of rupees on a capital investment of about 7 crores, or less than I per cent. per annum.

facts.text: Wage Board consisted of equal number of representatives of employers and working journalists and independent chairman Shri H. Divatia.

anchor.surface_text: ...companystiting of equal representatives of employers in relation to newspaper establishments and working journalists and appointed Shri H. Divatia, Retired Judge of the High Court of Judicature, Bombay, as the Chairman of the Board.

facts.text: Word 'minimum' was dropped from the Bill during discussion in Rajya Sabha.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that during the companyrse of discussion in the Rajya Sabha, the word minimum was dropped from the Bill wherever it occurred...

facts.text: Press Commission recommended minimum wage of Rs. 125 plus Rs. 25 dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: ...suggested that the basic minimum wage all over India for a working journalist should be Rs. 125 with Rs. 25 as dearness allowance making a total of Rs. 150.

issues.text: Whether the Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (the Act) is ultra vires the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: These petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution raise the question as to the vires of the Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscel- laneous Provisions Act, 1955  45 of 1955 , hereinafter referred to as the Act and the decision of the Wage Board companystituted thereunder.

issues.text: Whether the Act and the Wage Board decision infringe Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution (freedom of speech and expression including freedom of the press)

anchor.surface_text: K. Nambiar and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the petitioners in Petition No. 91 of 1957. -The Working Journalists Act, 1955, is ultra vires as it infringes the fundamental rights of the Petitioners guaranteed by the Constitution under Arts. 19  1   a , 19  1   g , 14 and 32. Article 19  1   a  which guarantees freedom of speech and expression includes the freedom of the employment of means to exercise those rights

issues.text: Whether the Act and the Wage Board decision infringe Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution (right to carry on business)

anchor.surface_text: The Act also violates the right guaranteed by Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution as it places unreasonable restraint on the petitioners freedom to carry on business  Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh, 1950 S. C. R. 759 cited with approval in Dwarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. The State of Uttar Pradesh

issues.text: Whether the Act violates Article 14 of the Constitution (equality and non-discrimination)

anchor.surface_text: The Act is discriminatory in character and violates Art. 14 of the Constitution. It gives the working journalists a more favoured treatment as companypared to other employees in several ways, statutory benefits by ,way of retrenchment companypensation, gratuity, limitation of the hours of work and leave

issues.text: Whether the Wage Board decision is void for violating principles of natural justice (audi alteram partem)

The Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, as amended  and it Was open to the Board to follow any arbitrary procedure disregarding the principle of audi alteration parted and as such the Act is unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: The Wage Board was number exercising legislative functions but functions, which were quasi-judicial in character. The intention of the Legislature was to assimilate the Wage Board as much as possible to an Industrial Tribunal companystituted under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

issues.text: Whether the pith and substance of the Act is regulation of conditions of service or infringement of fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(a) and 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: The Supreme Court has also in this companynection invoked the doctrine of pith and substance . issues.text: Whether the Act infringes Article 32 by not requiring reasons from Wage Board

anchor.surface_text: The Act companytravenes Art. 32 of the Constitution because it does number provide for giving any reasons for the decision to be made by the Wage Board.
